discussion.content: must be same forward domains, becasue with same forward domain, even different VLANs can do dhcp, but with vlans and different forward domains, DHCP will fail

comments.content: Correct. The answer here is not valid.

discussion.content:
i think A is correct, it is explained in:
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.2.4/cookbook/183521/checking-the-bridging-information-in-transparent-mode
The answer is A, which Levis states and the answer key states.

choices.A: Both interfaces must belong to the same forward domain.
choices.B: The role of the VLAN10 interface must be set to server.
choices.C: Both interfaces must have the same VLAN ID.
choices.D: Both interfaces must be in different VDOMs.

comments.content: Thanks for sharing these, it really helps explain more on how the answers are correct.

discussion.content:
C and D! You can set transparent and NAT mode in VDOM below is my reference. :) 
So A is incorrect!
B I think you can set a name for new VDOM but not system hostname, its configure globally the system hostname.
VDOM NAT and Transparent mode!
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.2.0/cookbook/986787/nat-and-transparent-mode

choices.C: Each VDOM maintains its own system time.
choices.D: Each VDOM maintains its own routing table.
choices.B: A FortiGate device has 64 VDOMs, created by default.
choices.A: The root VDOM is the management VDOM by default.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about virtual domains (VDOMs) are true? (Choose two.)

You are configuring the root FortiGate to implement the security fabric. You are configuring port10 to communicate with a downstream FortiGate. View the default
Edit Interface in the exhibit below:
//IMG//

When configuring the root FortiGate to communicate with a downstream FortiGate, which settings are required to be configured? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I think A and B
From https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.2.3/cookbook/788897/configuring-the-root-fortigate-and-downstream-fortigates 
In support of A:
"Under Network, turn on Device Detection."
In support of B:
"Enable FortiGate Telemetry."
if look into 6.2.3 links mentioned above, it seems AB, where as 6.0.0 has also mentioned about ip/network,,,,,,,, so I would say AB

the answer is b and c
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortigate/6.0.0/cookbook/724439/fortinet-security-fabric-installation
you dont need to enable device detection to configure the security fabric for fortigates, like EvanABS said, that would be for field equipment

comments.content: This is wrong sir. please recheck. I have read page 68 and 69 , nowhere is shows, you need to have IP / subnet mask configured.

discussion.content:
B and C (In root FG Telemetry and IP)

Device detection must be enable during downstream fortigate configuration.

Fortigate Security Study Guide page 68/69
Device Detection is only for field equipment

questions.question_text: What FortiGate components are tested during the hardware test? (Choose three.)

choices.D: It permits inline traffic inspection and firewalling without changing the IP scheme of the network.
choices.A: All interfaces of the transparent mode FortiGate device must be on different IP subnets.
choices.B: Ethernet packets are forwarded based on destination MAC addresses, not IP addresses.
choices.C: The transparent FortiGate is visible to network hosts in an IP traceroute.
choices.E: FortiGate acts as transparent bridge and forwards traffic at Layer 2.

questions.question_text: Which statements correctly describe transparent mode operation? (Choose three.)
